ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An survey of topics pertaining to gastronomy, restaurants, and food history.
This course teaches about the global origins of food, then spends the second half of the semester focused on the modern food scene in the US.
learned about food and gained better research skills!

lots of information on how food has shaped our country and the world through time. lots of talk about the evolution of food and other food practices and aspects. even covered modern day norms, how gender plays role, religious connotations, etc. Professor Freedman provided a very in-depth and complete picture.
This course really gave me new insights into world history. Using food as a lens made the topic really engaging, interesting, and novel.
never took a history course so learned a lot about narrowing my focus in paper writing
How to examine historical context and the impact history has in the present
writing
Learned about food across the globe throughout time and cultures.
I learned a lot about the development of cuisines and adaptation by modern restaurants. I also learned about the agriculture industry over time and its impacts on human life.
I learned a lot about food and culture, and the general course environment was really nice.

I learned about food histories of various regions as well as the developments of ideas about a proper diet. I learned how to think critically about the effects of certain diet promotions as well as how to recognize major cultural influences.
U developed a greater sense for food cosines around the world and I gained a lot of knowledge about the restaurant industry and food evolution in America especially.

This course is a perfect introduction history course for people who have not studied foodways. The analysis of foodways is quite valuable, and each region is touched on lightly, with room for independent exploration of any region in the independent papers. Just as well, the latter half of the term delves into "food" topics as food intersects with migration, race, gender, class, globalization, etc. I think that students quite literally get a "taste" of different areas of history, so, beyond the information about foodways and the historical information on different areas, I think the biggest skill gained was a greater certainty in what areas of history interest me.
I really enjoyed learning more about the historical roots of my favorite foods and understanding more.
S
learned so much about food and how it affects all facets of our lives!
A new appreciation of the impact of food on culture and society
How to write a good history essay, the societal relevance of food, history of restaurants.
I gained a lot of insight into what role food systems and cuisine play in global and American history.
I learned about the history of food, food practices, cuisine, and food culture. This class also made me think more about the food I am eating, where it comes from, and my relationship to it.
Thinking critically about food, connections between social movements and food, present haute cuisine, the aesthetics of food
I developed how to take information in history and apply it to the progression of food through time. This used critical thinking.
I learned about the history of food and how it impacts different demographics of people
Very expansive knowledge of the history of food and food culture. Overarching trends and phenomena that link the food histories of various cultures past and present.
The global history of cuisine (focusing on the major civilizations/religions/peoples): India, China, Islamic Empire, Medieval Europe, present-day America/globalization of cuisine.
History of food
an appreciation for the history of food

I learned a survey history of food from early man to modern times. We explored different global relationships to food and how that influenced the development of cuisine and cultural practices. This course enhanced my ability to view individual aspects of a culture as a lens for broader patterns. It also helped me understand the origin of modern attitudes towards food and track social changes over the last century.
I really enjoyed developing my writing skills and also being able to learn about the history of cuisine.
I improved on my writing skills and the research paper helped me evaluate a lot of sources and create evidence for an argument.

I learned that through studying food it is possible to gain deeper insights into peoples perceptions of their place in the world, what it means to be moral and what it means to be a good citizen or to belong. Eating, cooking and farming are some of the ways that we build our identities and judge the identities of others, and I began to understand that it is important to analyze history through the lens of food.
I learned about the history of food

We learned about the histories of different food cultures throughout the world (I think it was Chinese, Indian, different regional African cuisines, and a few others that escape my memory right now); in the latter half of the course, we focused primarily on American food cultures and food ways.
Everything about food and culture through a historical lens
That food has a very long history and that MANY factors from our daily life and contemporary society matter for what we eat.
A wide variety of food as a history, how it affects culture, and what it tells us about cultures.
I learned a lot about food and its different iterations across time and cultures.
history of food and writing essays
I learned about how food has evolved and how culturally important food is.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is good in that it is not too crazy of a workload and is open for exploration of individual interests within the realm of food. I would be interested to take it in a seminar format, however.
easy and fun course :)

Strengths: Professor Freedman is the most compelling lecturer I have come across at Yale so far. He is incredibly knowledgable and very funny. The information he provides is both relevant and entertaining, and his relaxed lecturing style (more like a conversation with stories incorporated as opposed to just spitting out facts at us) was very effective and kept the class engaged, even in a large lecture format.

This course was so engaging and interesting. I audited so did not do the discussion groups or papers, but I think they would have made the course even more enriching. The professor's lectures were by far my favorite lectures this semester. 

One major improvement that I think should be made: we should do more eating as a class. I often found myself feeling very hungry during lectures.
super interesting course i do wish the readings on the syllabus were specified better
Lectures were engaging.
papers graded harshly
The class is really interesting to listen to and discuss
Readings were hard to navigate (spread out, cost a lot overall).
Nothing in particular, if anything maybe the list of books to buy was too long when only parts of the books were read.
super fun lectures and readings!

Strengths: I liked how each lecture discussed a very different topic, which made me excited to go to every lecture. I also found all of the readings to be very interesting and insightful, and I genuinely enjoyed discussing them in discussion section. Weakness: sometimes the lecture seemed to discuss what was discussed in the reading almost verbatim, which made the lecture a little redundant.

The strengths is that the course covers good subjects. The weakness is that it is hard to know what information is actually important and that makes it hard to stay engaged. The grading on our essays also seemed very unreasonable at times and I felt as though I was marked down based on my graders opinions of an open-ended subject instead of how good my writing and argument actually were.
Sounds

This was an enjoyable survey course that dug into some really interesting questions about the development of different cuisines and the social, economic, and environmental implications of these developments.
I liked the lectures but the slides were random and discombobulated

I like the content, but I think the lectures could be improved by having more direct content on slides (like facts, etc) instead of just pictures and stories. It would also be helpful to be told how to write a history essay/exam because as a non-history major I did not know how to go into the essays/exams properly. The discussion section is the strongest part of the class!! Isin is the best and I learned the most during the class from her.

This class is very, very true to its name and is a class purely about the history of food and cuisine. However, the lectures were often slow and not engaging, as they sometimes lacked compelling visual aids and there were not as many connections to the modern day.

Strengths: lecturesPaul freedman is a great, engaging lecture, readingsusually not too heavy, engaging, and clear. 

Weaknesses: assignments were vague, engagement fell
Strength was having a teacher, Freedman, who was an expert on the material. He was able to facilitate the class well.
Interesting topics but painful section
Professor Freedman was an amazing lecturer. He retained my interest throughout the semester. My TA was very good, and the discussion sections felt useful and interesting.

Strength: Very interesting content
Weakness: Feels like a lack of continuity between units, but it didn't bother me much

Lecture format was effective, but could have been more accessible with uploaded slides/recordings. Lectures and readings somewhat disconnected, and weekly section is probably better off as optional. Midterm and final essay topics were flexible and fun!
Sometimes wish that they could focus more on the cultural aspect of food, but to be fair, it is a survey course so its limitations are justified.
All good

sometimes lecture was hard to follow or didn't go in a logical order. i would have appreciated a bit more info on some of the slides. section was good. did not enjoy having to write a 500 word reading response to make up for absences that i could not avoid (covid, etc.)

The course was strong in terms of grouping material and organizing lectures, but the material covered in each class felt slightly more example based than explanatory. It could potentially be helpful to cover more of the rationale behind certain choices or patterns in addition to saying what they were.
I think this course is great!
I enjoyed the lectures and the section with TA. I would say that maybe finding some way to evaluate students' learning on subjects covered after the midterm could improve engagement with the course.

I loved the weekly lecture and discussion section format. The lectures were extremely interesting, the readings always enjoyable and section helpful in bringing together lecture and reading. It would be nice to have slides during lecture, or some way of structuring the lecture for my notes and for better understanding what the key takeaways were. I also wish we had been given more support for the final paper.
strength: professor's knowledge of the course material
It is a very straight forward course, not a lot of variation in lectures

Strengths: It's interesting material! I love food and reading and writing about it, so that was nice. I also thought that the latter half of the course (which talked about American foodways and cultures) was quite personally relevant and further elaborated and elucidated American foodways throughout its history.

Weaknesses: I honestly think Professor Freedman should just skip talking about food cultures worldwide, and just focus on one. They're all quite interesting, but we blazed past India and China and different African regions, and I think those deserved greater attention.

Weaknesses: Readings were at times long and boring

Strengths: interesting course material, readings and lectures were closely tied

Strengths: the lectures were often the highlight of my week. Paul Freedman was amazing and knew so much about the topic. Also the first guest lecture we had was super interesting and had a cool interview/podcast style.
Weakness: I felt like the essays and exams were not always graded equally in that some TFs graded harsher than others.

- very interesting lectures
- fun activities during section
- engaging material

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in trying an EVST course.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because it is a fun and engaging course. Paul Freedman is also a good lecturer! There are also interesting guest lecturers throughout.
yes! it's pretty easy and light workload, and the material is very interesting. lots of freedom on papers to write about whatever interests you.
Of course. This has been my favorite class at Yale thus far. Anyone can take this course, and everyone SHOULD take this course.
Yes! It's so fun and interesting.
yes! great class if you are interested in food
I would recommend this to any student interested in learning the ways that our history shaped food and the way that food shapes our world.
yes but credit d
Yes, very chill and interesting if you are interested in the topic or just need a chill class In your schedule
Super interesting!
Yes, you learn a lot and the environment is not stressful.
yes! so fun and i learned a lot without being overwhelmed with work

Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone. It is a great course that discusses a lot of different topics (global history of food, American food and diet history, popular culture, sustainability just to name a few), so if you're interested in really anything pertaining to food you will find this class interesting. The readings are very interesting, and the lectures are as well.
I would if they are very interested in the subject.
Yes I would
S
I would if you're interested in food history across a very long time period. This class can be really specific at times and very broad at others which makes for an interesting dynamic.
Yes it was interesting
Definitely! One of my favorite classes so far.

I would only recommend this course to someone who is interested in learning about the history of food and cuisine. However, anyone who is looking for an exciting, engaging class about food to fill up their schedule should not take this class.
If a student is interested in food
If one is interested in how food progressed throughout different regions in the world and develop their own studies on food, then yes.
Yes. The first semester about global history aspect of food was a bit less interesting, but getting into the socioeconomic impacts of food history was very interesting.
If you are looking for a course on food history driven more by social phenomena, then yes. This is not really the course to study specific ingredients, dishes, and their histories.

Yes! Professor Freedman and this course as a whole was an absolute joy, a respite from the craze of normal Yale courses! The readings were fascinating and relatable. A truly fun class that anyone can get something out of. I will say, however, how much you get out of this class is exactly proportional to how much you put in. It helps so, so much if you are already interested in and passionate about food and food history, but how could you not like food.
Yes, its great to learn about food
yes! good, especially for underclassmen to get a feel for a yale lecture course. probably a gut for upperclassmen

I would recommend it to another student, especially if they are interested in food history. I think that, because of the niche topics covered in certain lectures, it is very interesting if the subject is something you are already inclined to care about.
Yes! This is a wonderful course and you learn a lot.
Yes. Very interesting class taught by a great professor.

I definitely recommend this course! The non-structure of the lectures was a bit hard for me to get used to, but did not detract from the course. If you are interested in studying food at all, this is a very enjoyable and interesting class, and a really good introduction to the many different ways through which people study food.
no
If you need a class that is not very demanding.

No.
Some readings were good and interesting, but I honestly just didn't enjoy the course because it was overall a little bit boringand it's about such an interesting topic too!
Absolutely! Super fun and interesting survey course
Yes, because it's a very interesting and fun course.
If youre interested in food, food policy, or food sustainability, yes.
I would recommend. One of my favorite classes at Yale so far. Not an easy/gut A though, so maybe consider credit/D to really enjoy the class.
yes if they are interested in food and are good essay writers
No. Grading scale was not the same for each TA. Unfair for some students that we in sections with harsh graders.
Yes, this course was very fun and I loved the material.
